abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Kyrgyz Urban Transport
            Project were as follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project are as follows: It is important to be flexible and
            to adjust a project design in response to changing
            conditions on the ground, even if it means making
            substantial changes late in the preparation process (or for
            that matter after a project is formally approved.) It is
            necessary to carefully consider the trade offs between
            ensuring successful physical implementation of a project
            through reliance on foreign expertise and the desire to
            achieve significant capacity building of local institutions
            (both public and private) over the medium term. It is
            important to conduct a careful assessment of the capability
            of the private sector to assimilate these public sector
            assets taking into account current market conditions. It is
            important to design pavement overlays somewhat thicker to
            avoid rapid deterioration of the pavement surface prior to
            the next likely maintenance cycle, in countries where
            regular road maintenance activities remain uncertain.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Kyrgyz Urban Transport Project, aims
            at providing reliable mobility to the populations of the
            cities of Bishkek, Osh, and Jalalabad, through the
            restoration of urban roads, its maintenance and
            rehabilitation. The components include: 1) civil works for
            the rehabilitation, and maintenance of urban public
            networks. Rehabilitation treatments may include complete
            reconstruction, to asphalt overlays, including drainage
            improvements. Routine maintenance supplementary funds will
            also be provided for those sections of roads not included
            for other rehabilitation treatment; 2) consulting services
            for the engineering design, and construction supervision,
            introducing design technologies for road maintenance, and
            rehabilitation, condition assessment, economic
            prioritization, and international procurement practices. In
            addition to on-the-job training, consultants will assist in
            establishing standard contracting practices, to be
            documented in a set of manuals for further application
            throughout the country. Additionally, assistance will be
            provided for implementation of a computerized maintenance
            management system; and, a Municipal Road Finance Study will
            address accessibility to funding resources; and, 3) project
            management, and Project Implementation Unit (PIU) operating
            costs, will be funded, including PIU's financial
            audits, and repayment of the Project Preparation Facility.

443648.trustfund:
TF039743-KYRGYZ - URBAN TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF035614-KYRGYZ REPUBLIC - URBAN
            TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF035503-KYRGYZ REPUBLIC - TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF035422-KYRGYZ REPUBLIC - TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF025289-PHRD-URBAN TRANSPORT PROJECT,TF020889-SOCIAL SCIENTISTS NETWORK IN

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Urban Transport Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
Construction of the Kyrgyz Urban
            Transport Project will involve repair, and installation of
            underground utility ducts, roads rehabilitation, and
            upgrade, including leveling, and curb reconstruction,
            expected to generate adverse environmental impacts. Soil
            erosion, and water pollution will occur as a result of
            underground excavations, and drainage works, further
            mobilizing contaminants such as lead, and cadmium, in
            addition to construction sediments. Construction of
            trenches, and road widening will potentially damage trees,
            and tree roots, and, the usual air, and noise pollution will
            occur as a result of construction dust, and
            equipment/vibration noise. Mitigating measures include: 1)
            contaminated soils, and toxic wastes, will be tested, and
            disposed of in accordance with the country's
            environmental protection regulations; 2) construction plans
            for drainage systems, surface channels, sediment traps, and
            discharge pits will be submitted to the Project Authority
            for approval; 3) trenches will be constructed manually to
            reduce damaging of tree roots, and attempts will be made to
            minimize damaging the adjacent greenbelt areas. Trees will
            be replanted as needed; 4) water spraying will reduce dust
            and air pollution, materials will be stored in sheltered
            areas, and, debris will be dampened prior to disposal; and,
            5) chemicals, and lubricants will be contained according to regulations.
